description: From Latin haemorrhagia, from Ancient Greek αἱμορραγία (haimorrhagía, “a violent bleeding”), from αἱμορραγής (haimorrhagḗs, “bleeding violently”), from αἷμα (haîma, “blood”) + -ραγία (-ragía), from ῥηγνύναι (rhēgnúnai, “to break, burst”).

nouns.description: hemorrhage (countable and uncountable, plural hemorrhages) (American spelling)

entries.meaning: A heavy release of blood within or from the body.
examples: We got news that he died of a hemorrhage.
the fiscal hemorrhage that has resulted from financial globalization

verbs.description: hemorrhage (third-person singular simple present hemorrhages, present participle hemorrhaging, simple past and past participle hemorrhaged) (American spelling)

entries.meaning: (transitive, figuratively) To lose (something) in copious and detrimental quantities.
examples: The company hemorrhaged money until eventually it went bankrupt.
